title.value: Extracting Person Names from User Generated Text: Named-Entity Recognition for Combating Human Trafficking
title.justification: The title clearly states the main focus of the paper which is the application of Named Entity Recognition (NER) techniques to extract person names from user-generated text, specifically for combating human trafficking.
title.quote: Extracting Person Names from User Generated Text: Named-Entity Recognition for Combating Human Trafficking

extractions.description: This paper addresses the challenge of extracting person names from online escort advertisement websites, which are used for advertising victims of human trafficking. It presents NEAT (Name Extraction Against Trafficking), a system that combines rule-based and dictionary extractors with a contextualized language model, significantly improving the accuracy of name extraction in this challenging domain compared to state-of-the-art NER models.

type.justification: The paper involves an empirical study where a new system called NEAT is developed, tested, and evaluated against baseline models using precision, recall, and F1-score analysis.
type.quote: We evaluate the performance of the baseline models and NEAT for name extraction from text and display the results in tables 2, 3 and 4.

name.justification: The research paper primarily deals with Named Entity Recognition, a sub-field of Natural Language Processing, applied to identify and extract person names from text.
name.quote: Thus, while the general task of Named Entity Recognition (NER) usually includes diverse entities such as person names, organizations, and geolocations, in this paper, we focus on person name extraction from escort ads for combating human trafficking.

name.justification: The primary method discussed in the paper is Named Entity Recognition (NER), which is used for extracting person names from text data.
name.quote: Most advanced NER models are trained on annotated structured text corpora and/or rely on contextual information for identifying entities.

name.justification: NEAT is introduced as a novel system for extracting person names from escort advertisements, combining a rule-based extractor with a contextualized language model.
name.quote: We introduce a name extractor, NEAT (Name Extraction Against Trafficking), that enhances a core rule-based extractor with masked language models to perform disambiguation.

is_contributed.justification: The model NEAT is introduced as a new approach specifically within the scope of this paper.
is_contributed.quote: We introduce a name extractor, NEAT (Name Extraction Against Trafficking), that enhances a core rule-based extractor with masked language models to perform disambiguation.

is_executed.justification: The models, including NEAT, were executed and tested for performance metrics such as F1-score in the experiments.
is_executed.quote: We evaluate the performance of the baseline models and NEAT for name extraction from text and display the results in tables 2, 3 and 4.

is_compared.justification: NEAT's performance is compared against other NER models like TJBatch and Transformer-Bert.
is_compared.quote: We show that NEAT outperforms the previous state-of-the-art NER model for name extraction from escort advertisements, with an average of 19% improvement in F1 for our two domain-specific datasets.

referenced_paper_title.justification: NEAT is introduced in this paper as a novel contribution, thus it does not reference an external source specifically as its origin.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We introduce a name extractor, NEAT (Name Extraction Against Trafficking), that enhances a core rule-based extractor with masked language models to perform disambiguation.

name.justification: Transformer-BERT is mentioned as a baseline NLP model that was fine-tuned on the CoNLL-2003 Named Entity Recognition dataset for comparison.
name.quote: Transformer-Bert – A BERT model (Devlin et al., 2018) fine-tuned on the English version of the standard CoNLL-2003 Named Entity Recognition dataset.

is_contributed.justification: Transformer-Bert is a pre-existing model that was used as a baseline for comparison within this research context.
is_contributed.quote: Transformer-Bert – A BERT model (Devlin et al., 2018) fine-tuned on the English version of the standard CoNLL-2003 Named Entity Recognition dataset.

is_executed.justification: The model was executed as a baseline for performance comparison in the experiments conducted in the paper.
is_executed.quote: The results (Figure 1) show that both the domain-specific and general NER models fail in identifying certain person names in the ad.

is_compared.justification: Transformer-Bert is used as a baseline for comparison against the proposed NEAT model.
is_compared.quote: We show that NEAT outperforms the previous state-of-the-art NER model for name extraction from escort advertisements, with an average of 19% improvement in F1 for our two domain-specific datasets.

referenced_paper_title.value: BERT: pre-training of deep bidirectional transformers for language understanding
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper describing the BERT model provides the foundational description of the model variant used in this research.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Transformer-Bert – A BERT model (Devlin et al., 2018) fine-tuned on the English version of the standard CoNLL-2003 Named Entity Recognition dataset.

name.justification: TJBatch is identified as a rule-based named entity extractor that was previously the state-of-the-art in the human trafficking domain.
name.quote: TJBatch – The state-of-the-art named entity extractor (Dubrawski et al., 2015; Chambers et al., 2019) in the human trafficking domain.

is_contributed.justification: TJBatch is a pre-existing rule-based model used for comparison to show improvements of the NEAT model.
is_contributed.quote: TJBatch – The state-of-the-art named entity extractor (Dubrawski et al., 2015; Chambers et al., 2019) in the human trafficking domain.

is_executed.justification: TJBatch's performance was evaluated in this study for extracting person names in escort ads as a comparison.
is_executed.quote: The results (Figure 1) show that both the domain-specific and general NER models fail in identifying certain person names in the ad.

is_compared.justification: TJBatch was used as a benchmark to assess how NEAT improves over previous methods.
is_compared.quote: We show that NEAT outperforms the previous state-of-the-art NER model for name extraction from escort advertisements, with an average of 19% improvement in F1 for our two domain-specific datasets.

referenced_paper_title.value: Leveraging publicly available data to discern patterns of human-trafficking activity
referenced_paper_title.justification: The reference to Dubrawski et al., 2015, provides the primary source for the TJBatch extractor's description in human trafficking context.
referenced_paper_title.quote: TJBatch – The state-of-the-art named entity extractor (Dubrawski et al., 2015; Chambers et al., 2019) in the human trafficking domain.

name.justification: CoNLL-2003 is mentioned as a standard dataset used for training and evaluating NER models.
name.quote: Transformer-Bert – A BERT model (Devlin et al., 2018) fine-tuned on the English version of the standard CoNLL-2003 Named Entity Recognition dataset.

referenced_paper_title.value: Introduction to the CoNLL-2003 shared task: Language-independent named entity recognition
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper provides the basis for the CoNLL-2003 dataset's use in shared NER tasks.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Transformer-Bert – A BERT model (Devlin et al., 2018) fine-tuned on the English version of the standard CoNLL-2003 Named Entity Recognition dataset.

name.justification: HT1K is introduced as a domain-specific dataset collected to test name extraction for human trafficking ads.
name.quote: HT1K: 994 examples crawled from an escort advertisement website.

referenced_paper_title.justification: This dataset was created and contributed by the authors of this paper specifically for their research, so it does not rely on existing, referenced literature.
referenced_paper_title.quote: HT1K: 994 examples crawled from an escort advertisement website.

name.justification: HT2K is another domain-specific dataset created for evaluating name extraction in the context of human trafficking ads, similar to HT1K.
name.quote: HT2K: 1970 examples crawled from a different escort advertisement website.

referenced_paper_title.justification: This dataset was generated as part of the research and not from an external source, thus no reference title is provided.
referenced_paper_title.quote: HT2K: 1970 examples crawled from a different escort advertisement website.
